subject: Re: [junit] @BeforeClass throws NullPointerException

messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> On 9/28/05, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:

> Well, the current behavior seems to confuse the hell out of the poster as
> well, and I side with him: why would you have to declare your method static?
> I thought we would finally be rid of this constraint to declare fields
> static to maintain state?

It makes perfect sense that @BeforeClass would set up class-level state
and @Before would set up instance-level state. It's just a shame that
the compiler, which used to help here (with TestSetup) doesn't with the
corresponding annotation.

> I think you should just use @Before and not @BeforeClass. Don't do
> > class-level setup as a performance hack; it creates more problems than
> > it solves.
>
> I don't believe it's a hack: it's scoped initialization of resources. We use
> this in Java all the time (static fields, fields, local variables).

I judged by the test code that the OP was using it as a way to avoid
initializing the same data for all the tests in the test case class. I
guessed that it was a performance hack, since I've seen 1000 people want
to do the same thing. I suppose we should let the OP tell me whether it
really was or wasn't a hack.

> You need a resource at the class level, you initialize it in a BeforeClass
> method. You need a resource at the method level, you initialize it in a
> Before method.

Right... so don't initialize an instance-level resource with
@BeforeClass. Either use @Before or make the resource class-level. I'm
pretty sure that's what I said, along with "And by the way, why do you
want a class-level resource here? I'm worried you might be trying to
optimize unnecessarily and possibly counterproductively."

> Doesn't get any simpler or more intuitive than that...

I agree; so what's your point again?
